description: From French carnaval, from Italian carnevale, possibly from the Latin phrase carnem lev훮men ("meat dismissal"). Other scholars suggest Latin carnu훮lia ("meat-based country feast") or carrus n훮v훮lis ("boat wagon", "float") instead.

entries.meaning: Any of a number of festivals held just before the beginning of Lent.
A festive occasion marked by parades and sometimes special foods and other entertainment.
(US) A traveling amusement park, called a funfair in British English.
examples: We all got to ride the merry-go-round when they brought their carnival to town.
When the carnival came to town, every one wanted some cotton candy.
